In the present work, an alkoxide sol-gel method was applied to prepare Pd/MgO catalysts. The sol-gel procedure was followed by supercritical drying (aerogels) or conventional drying (xerogels) in a furnace. These materials were compared with the impregnated samples. The Pd loading was 1 wt% in all the cases. The as-prepared catalysts were characterized by a set of physicochemical methods. Both the type of the Pd precursor and the preparation route were found to affect the porous structure of the materials as well as the dispersion of the palladium particles and their localization over the MgO support. Both the xerogel and incipient wetness impregnation methods lead to a narrower pore size distribution in comparison to the aerogel technique. The most dispersed particles with an average size of ∼ 2.0–2.2 nm were observed for the samples prepared by xerogel and impregnation methods. In the case of aerogel-prepared samples, metallic palladium particles possess bimodal distribution with average diameters of 4.3 and 8.4 nm. The best catalytic performance in acetylene hydrogenation to ethylene (50 % acetylene conversion at 37 °C with selectivity ∼60 %) was observed for the Pd/MgO catalyst prepared via the aerogel route using [Pd(NH3)4](NO3)2. Compared to other samples, this material is characterized by relatively weak metal-support interactions and the availability of active sites for reactants, which ensures the kinetic mode of the hydrogenation reaction (Ea = 74.9 kJ/mol). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Sol-gel synthesis Magnesium oxide Aerogels Xerogels Palladium nanoparticles Acetylene hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nowadays, ethylene remains one of the most important intermediate products of the petrochemical industry. Being a monomer of polyethylene, it constitutes about 30 % of total polymer production [1]. Industrial processes of ethylene production are mainly based on cracking of petroleum fractions and dehydrogenation of saturated hydrocarbons. Along with ethylene, impurities of acetylene are inevitably formed for 3–5 to 10 % [2], which are removed by selective hydrogenation of acetylene on palladium catalysts [3], because acetylene is a poison for ethylene polymerization catalysts [4]. Alternative methods for producing ethylene are also currently being developed. A promising method for ethylene synthesis is the selective hydrogenation of acetylene obtained by the pyrolysis of natural gas or by the carbide method [5,6]. This process is also carried out on palladium catalysts. Among the catalysts developed for acetylene hydrogenation, palladium-containing systems are considered to be the most efficient [5,7–10]. Despite the acetylene conversion, the selectivity toward ethylene is also a very important characteristic of the acetylene hydrogenation process. However, it is known that palladium can absorb H2 in a hydrogen-containing environment to form β-hydrides [11–13]. It is believed that the presence of palladium β-hydride promotes the complete hydrogenation of alkynes to saturated hydrocarbons, thus reducing the selectivity for olefins [14,15]. Hence, the suppression of the palladium β-hydride formation is necessary to enhance the semi-hydrogenation selectivity. It should be noted that the surface acidic sites of the support can exert negatively the selectivity for alkenes. Thus, the presence of strong acidic sites promotes such a side reaction as dimerization of acetylene to 1,3-butadiene [16–18]. Therefore, materials with a low surface acidity are more preferable to be used as supports for the selective hydrogenation process. The effect of weak and strong acidic sites on the efficiency of acetylene hydrogenation was intensively studied during the last decade [19–22]. In the case of alumina support, its thermal treatment reduces the surface acidity. A decrease in the number of acidic sites on the surface of alumina improves the selectivity for ethylene significantly [19,20]. He et al. [22] investigated a hydrotalcite-based palladium catalyst. In this research, high values of conversion and selectivity were explained by a good dispersion of the active component on the support's surface, which was achieved due to the presence of both basic and acidic sites. Another way to reduce the acidic sites on the surface of alumina is the addition of some modifiers. Among such additives, magnesium oxide is often used [23,24]. For instance, Shivtsov et al. [25] reported the influence of the composition of MgO-Al2O3 supports on the selectivity of Pd-containing catalysts in the dehydrogenation of perhydrophenazine. An increase in the MgO loading resulted in a higher concentration of electron-donor sites and a lower concentration of electron-acceptor sites. All this increased the selectivity toward the target products. A similar approach was used by Feng J. and Li D. with coauthors to increase the selectivity of the acetylene hydrogenation process [26–28]. However, the number of works devoted to the study of hydrogenation processes on supports with a large number of basic sites, such as MgO, is scarce [29,30]. In recent years, a new type of hydrogenation catalysts, namely, single-atom catalysts, has been discovered. These catalysts exhibit a very high efficiency in hydrogenation of acetylene as well. As it follows from the name, the active component in these catalysts is distributed in the form of isolated atoms. MgO was reported to be an appropriate support for stabilizing isolated palladium atoms [31,32]. For example, Chao et al. [33] studied the single-atom 0.001 %Pd/MgO catalyst in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene. It was proposed that heterolytic dissociation of H2 on a Pd atom and a nearby oxygen anion takes place to form OH groups, which may be involved in the acetylene hydrogenation reaction. Contrarily, Pd single atoms demonstrated negligible activity in the hydrogenation of ethylene, which accounts for high selectivity. It is important to note that for effective diffusion of the reagent to the surface of the active component, as well as from the surface to the external environment, the support should possess a tailored porous structure [34,35]. In the case of the selective hydrogenation of acetylene, the presence of diffusion limitations can contribute to the complete hydrogenation process due to the re-adsorption of ethylene. Consequently, the search for supports with an optimal porosity and methods of their preparation remains to be an actual task. Among the materials currently attracting attention of the researchers, aerogel materials demonstrate a highly developed porous structure [36–40]. Previously, an aerogel method based on supercritical drying of hydroxide gels to obtain materials of different compositions was developed [37,41–43]. This method was modified to introduce the active component in the sol-gel synthesis stage. Thus, aerogel-prepared V-Mg-O nanocrystalline catalysts showed higher activity in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane compared to the systems described in the literature [41]. The use of the aerogel method for the preparation of Pd/MgO catalysts allowed for obtaining materials with a uniform distribution of the dispersed palladium particles within the MgO matrix [42]. Taking into account all the aforesaid, the following conclusions can be made. There are three main factors defining the catalytic activity. Since the acetylene hydrogenation reaction is size-sensitive, the dispersion of the active metal (palladium) is of high importance to achieve high acetylene conversion along with appropriate selectivity toward ethylene. The second factor is the acidity of the surface of the support. The presence of strong acid sites significantly decreases the selectivity of the process. Finally, the porous structure of the support is also very important. It should provide efficient diffusion of the reagents to the active sites of the catalyst. Therefore, the choice of suitable support is an actual task. Palladium supported on magnesium oxide seems to be a very promising system, which satisfies the mentioned requirements. However, just a few papers are devoted to the development and detailed investigation of such catalysts. Moreover, the catalyst preparation conditions have not been varied widely yet. Thereby, the purpose of this work was to investigate the effect of the preparation route of the Pd/MgO catalysts on their performance in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. Thus, a series of the Pd/MgO catalysts containing 1 wt% of palladium was synthesized. Three preparation routes were used: a sol-gel synthesis followed by drying under supercritical or atmospheric conditions, and an incipient impregnation method. The catalyst texture, the dispersity of the Pd particles, their localization, and the electronic state of palladium were studied. The catalytic performance of the prepared materials was tested in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene. As a result, the regularities between the catalyst structure and the catalytic activity were established, which are useful for the further development of efficient MgO-based catalytic systems. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Methanol (J.T. Baker, Phillipsburg, NJ, USA), toluene (Component-Reactive, Moscow, Russia), magnesium ribbon (Aldrich, Burlington, MA, USA), 14.89 wt% Pd(NO3)2 solution and [Pd(NH3)4]Cl2 (JSC “Krastsvetmet”, Krasnoyarsk, Russia) were used as-received, without further purification. [Pd(NH3)4](NO3)2 was prepared from [Pd(NH3)4]Cl2 by substituting chloride ions with nitrate ions via the reaction with AgNO3. 2.2 Preparation of the aerogel MgO support The aerogel MgO support (MgO-AP) was prepared via an aerogel technique. In the first stage, a metallic magnesium ribbon (2.4 g) was subjected to the reaction with methanol (mL). In order to initialize this reaction, the mixture was heated up to the boiling temperature. The heating was stopped when an intensive release of hydrogen occurred. Toluene (100 mL) was added to the obtained solution as a stabilizer. Then, magnesium methoxide was hydrolyzed dropwise with water (3.7 mL) at room temperature. During 1 h of such a slow hydrolysis, a homogeneous gel of magnesium hydroxide was formed. The obtained gel was placed into an autoclave (AmAr Equipments Ltd., Mumbai, India) and heated up to 265 °C for 3 h. Along with this, the pressure in the autoclave reached 80 atm. Finally, the autoclave was degassed to remove the solvent. The dried gel was calcined in a muffle by heating up to 500 °C for 5 h and maintained at this temperature for 3 h. 2.3 Preparation of the Pd/MgO catalysts To prepare the Pd/MgO catalysts, three synthesis routes were applied. In each route, two Pd precursors were used: (A) – [Pd(NH3)4](NO3)2, and (B) – Pd(NO3)2. The first synthesis route is based on the aerogel technique described in Section 2.2. An aqua-methanol solution of the Pd precursor (A or B) was added dropwise to the freshly prepared homogeneous gel of magnesium hydroxide. The use of aqua-methanol solutions is due to the need to reduce the amount of water in magnesium hydroxide gels stabilized by the organic phase. The resulting gel was dried under supercritical conditions in the autoclave. In the second route, a modified xerogel method was used. The main procedures of this route are similar to the previous one excluding the supercritical drying. In this case, the gel was dried in air. Thus, the freshly prepared homogeneous gel of magnesium hydroxide was mixed with the Pd precursor (A or B), homogenized, and dried in a Petri dish at room temperature for 2 h and then in a furnace at 200 °C for 2 h. In the third case, a conventional incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method was used. The MgO-AP support was impregnated with an aqua-ethanol solution of the Pd precursor (A or B). Here, the use of ethanol as a co-solvent allowed us to minimize the drying shrinkage of the porous structure due to less surface tension. On the other hand, water is required to dissolve [Pd(NH3)4](NO3)2, which is poorly soluble in ethanol. All these Pd/MgO samples were calcined in a temperature-programmed regime via heating up to 500 °C for 3 h. The temperature ramping rate was minimal in a range where Mg(OH)2 transits to MgO. 2.4 Characterization of the catalysts by physicochemical methods In order to determine the chemical composition of the prepared Pd/MgO samples, atomic absorption spectroscopy was applied using a Solaar IC-3000 spectrometer. The measured content of palladium in the prepared samples was 0.70 ± 0.03 wt% (aerogel samples, route 1), 0.91 ± 0.02 wt% (xerogel samples, route 2), and 0.81 ± 0.05 wt% (IWI samples, route 3). Low-temperature nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were recorded using a Sync200 (3P instruments, Odelzhausen, Germany) instrument. Before measurements, all samples were degassed in a vacuum of less than 1 Pa at 300 °C for 3 h. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the specific surface area (SSA). Total pore volume (Vtotal) was determined from the maximum adsorption value at P/P0 = 0.995. Pore size distributions were calculated from the desorption branch using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Most frequent pore size values (Dmf) were determined from the pore size distributions and average pore size (Dav) was calculated from the equation Dav=4SSA/Vtotal. Note that to make accurate conclusions regarding the possible effects of the texture on the catalytic properties, the samples were molded into grains of 0.1–0.25 mm in size. The same grain size was used for catalytic experiments. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the prepared samples was performed using an X'TRA (Thermo ARL, Ecublens, Switzerland) diffractometer with a CuKα radiation source. The patterns were registered in a 2θ angle range of 10–70° with an accumulation time in each point of 5 s. Diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra were recorded between 190 and 800 nm using a UV–Vis spectrometer Cary 300 (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA) and DRA-CA-3300 integrating sphere (Varian, Inc., Palo Alto, CA, USA) with a Spectralon® standard as a reference. The UV–vis spectra were transformed into the Kubelka–Munk function F(R) [44]. In order to estimate the size of the PdO particles, the value of the energy gap (Eg) width was determined using the Tauc approach. For direct transitions, the plots [F(R ∞) × hν]2 versus hν, where F(R ∞) is the Kubelka-Munk function for an infinitely thick sample and hλ is the energy of the incident photon, were fitted to a sum of an arctangent curve. It is known that the Eg value for the bulk PdO lies in a range of 0.8–1.5 eV [45,46]. At the same time, the asymptotic Eg value estimated according to the Tauc approach for the isolated Pd2+ ions in the oxygen surroundings for Pd/Al2O3 is ∼ 2.35 eV [47]. The morphology of the samples was studied by scanning electron microscopy using a Regulus 8230 electron microscope (Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan) with a cold emission at the value of probe electron energy of 5 kV. The microscopic images of the surface of the samples were registered in a mode of secondary electrons, which were emitted from the surface layer of less than 5 nm in thickness. Characterization of the structure and microstructure of the catalysts by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR TEM) was performed on a JEM-2010 (JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) electron microscope working at an accelerating voltage of 200 kW and a lattice limit resolution of 0.14 nm. The microscope is equipped with an XFlash energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometer (Bruker, Billerica, MA, U.S.) with a semiconductor Si detector with an energy resolution of 130 eV. For TEM studies, each sample was supported on perforated carbon substrates attached to copper or molybdenum grids using an ultrasonic dispersant. The sample was placed in an alcohol medium deposited on an ultrasonic dispersant, after which evaporation and subsequent precipitation of the sample particles on a copper mesh occurred. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were performed using a flow-through setup. In a typical experiment, a specimen of the Pd/MgO sample (200 mg) was loaded into a quartz reactor, heated in a flow of dry air up to 500 °C, and kept at this temperature for 1 h. After cooling, the reactor was fed with a mixture consisting of 10 vol% H2 and 90 vol% N2. The total gas flow was 57.8 mL/min. The reactor was kept at 30 °C for 15 min and then heated to 500 °C with a ramping rate of 10 °C/min. The hydrogen concentration was measured using a GAMMA-100 hydrogen gas analyzer (FSUE “SPA “Analitpribor”, Smolensk, Russia) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. Immediately after the TPR experiment, the sample was tested in a temperature-programmed hydride decomposition (TPHD) mode. The reactor was cooled down to 30 °C in the same mixture and then heated again to 250 °C. The formation and decomposition of PdHx with the release of hydrogen take place during this process. The amount of the released hydrogen allows for comparing the sizes of Pd particles. X-ray photoelectron spectra were recorded using a SPECS spectrometer (SPECS GmbH, Berlin, Germany) working at an AlKα irradiation (hν = 1486.6 eV, 150 W). The binding energy (BE) scale was preliminarily calibrated with respect to the position of core levels of gold and copper (Au 4f7/2 – 84.0 eV and Cu 2p3/2 – 932.67 eV). It should be noted that the pressure of the residual gases in the chamber during the measurements did not exceed 8 × 10−9 bar. The samples were fixed on a standard holder using double-sided conductive copper tape (Scotch 3M©). To calibrate the measured spectra, a Mg 2p line (BE = 50.5 eV) from magnesium in MgO was used as an internal standard [48,49]. The integral line intensities were measured from the areas of the respective regions (Mg 2p, C 1s, Pd 3d, and O 1s). The determination of the relative content of elements on the surface of the samples and the ratio of their atomic concentrations was carried out by the integral intensities of photoelectronic lines corrected for the corresponding atomic sensitivity coefficients [50]. The obtained spectral information was processed using the XPSPeak 4.1 software. The samples were examined after the reduction in hydrogen at 500 °C for 1 h. The reduction was performed directly in the chamber of the photoelectronic spectrometer equipped with a high-pressure cell, which allowed for treating the samples in various gas media at pressures up to 1 atm and in the temperature range of 50–500 °C. In this case, the samples were rubbed into a stainless-steel mesh welded by spot welding to a standard holder. The reduction was carried out at a hydrogen pressure in the cell ∼ 0.3 atm. After the reduction, the sample was cooled in hydrogen. Then, hydrogen was pumped out of the cell and the sample was transferred to the analyzer chamber without intermediate contact with the atmosphere. 2.5 Catalytic performance of the catalysts in the hydrogenation of acetylene The prepared Pd/MgO catalysts were tested in the hydrogenation of acetylene. The samples were preliminarily reduced in hydrogen at 500 °C for 3 h. A specimen of the catalyst (5.0 mg) was mixed with an inert diluent (quartz) to form a fixed bed of 1 cm3 in volume. A fraction of 0.1-0.2 mm was used in these experiments. Prior to the catalytic tests, the reactor with the loaded catalyst was purged with nitrogen for 10 min. The experiments were carried out in a flow mode at atmospheric pressure in a temperature range of 20–90 °C. The reaction temperature was maintained using a thermostat. The reaction mixture containing 4 vol% acetylene and 96 vol% hydrogen was passed through the glass reactor of 1 cm in diameter with a gas flow rate of 100 mL/min. The composition of the outlet reaction mixture was determined using a Chromos GC-1000 chromatograph equipped with a capillary column (25 m × 0.32 mm; T = 60 °C; fixed phase - SiO2) and a flame ionization detector. Nitrogen was used as a carrier gas. Each catalyst sample was tested for at least three times. The experimental error did not exceed 10 %. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the Pd/MgO catalysts Fig. 1 and Table 1 present the textural characteristics of the Pd/MgO catalysts obtained from the low-temperature nitrogen adsorption/desorption data. Both the type of the metal precursor and the preparation route were found to influence the porous structure of the samples. For the aerogel- and xerogel-prepared samples (1A, 1B, 2A, and 2B), isotherms show no noticeable plateau at high P/P0 values (Fig. 1a and c) and can be attributed to Type IV according to IUPAC classification [51,52]. The aerogel-prepared samples 1A and 1B are characterized by relatively wide pore size distributions. The samples prepared via the xerogel route (2A and 2B) demonstrate the SSA values comparable to those of the aerogel-prepared samples (1A and 1B) but the Dmf values are smaller. This indicates that the size of the MgO crystallites in these samples is similar but the degree of crystallite packing is higher for samples 2A and 2B. This seems to be a result of the shrinkage of the porous structure that occurred during the drying at ambient conditions. In the case of the 2A sample, such shrinkage led to the formation of a certain number of larger pores, as indicated by the 4Vpore/SSA value and the pore size distribution presented in Fig. 1d. In the case of the IWI-prepared samples (3A and 3B), the SSA and Vpore values are noticeably lower. Both the shrinkage of the porous structure and the enlargement of the MgO crystallites contribute to these changes. The adsorption isotherms correspond to Type IV and possess a noticeable adsorption hysteresis due to the mesoporous nature of the samples. The well-defined plateau on the isotherms (Fig. 1e) indicates the absence of large pores in these samples. Only the pores smaller than 20 nm are observed. The use of the Pd(NO3)2 solution as a precursor results in the shift of pore size distributions to larger pores and leads to lower SSA values. The reason for this is assumed to be the presence of nitric acid in the commercial Pd(NO3)2 solution. When this solution is added to the Mg(OH)2 gel, magnesium hydroxide can react with HNO3, thus breaking some of the polymeric chains in Mg(OH)2. In addition, the formed magnesium nitrate Mg(NO3)2 decomposes in the calcination stage with an exothermic effect [53]. Both of these factors influence the porous structure of the samples. The XRD patterns of the samples regardless of the preparation route are represented mainly by the reflections assigned to the MgO phase (Fig. S1, Supplementary Information). The intensities of the PdO-assigned reflections are quite low, which is due to the small size of the Pd species. The trace amounts of Mg(OH)2 are also seen in the patterns. The size of MgO crystallites is estimated to be 6 nm (aerogel samples), 7 nm (xerogel samples), and 10 nm (IWI samples). The morphology of the samples obtained via the three preparation routes is shown in Fig. 2 . Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images taken at the same magnification evidently illustrate the differences between the samples. As seen, the aerogel technique allowed the preparation of the nanostructured material with a fluffy morphology (Fig. 2a). The size of the primary aggregates of particles seems to be the lowest one. In the case of the xerogel-prepared sample (2A), the primary aggregates are noticeably large in size (Fig. 2b). This sample possesses a coralline structure composed of nanoflakes. Finally, the IWI-prepared sample (3A) expectedly reminds the aerogel-prepared sample (1A) in morphology but with some differences (Fig. 2c). The presence of coarse flake-like aggregates along with the degraded fluffy structure is well seen. Supposedly, these changes in morphology are due to the partial dissolution of the aerogel-prepared MgO aggregates during the impregnation stage. Previously, UV–vis spectroscopy was shown to be a useful technique to assess the state of Pd species supported on alumina [47]. However, the MgO-based catalysts have not been studied in detail by this technique yet. Fig. 3 presents the UV–vis spectra for the Pd/MgO samples after calcination at 500 °C in air. Corresponding pure MgO supports were used as references. As reported for Pd/Al2O3 systems, which are characterized by weak metal-support interactions, the structure of small PdO species is already completely formed at the calcination temperatures of 500– 600 °C. Such systems demonstrate a d-d transition band at 450 nm and a metal-ligand charge transfer band at 200 nm [54,55]. It is clear that the main qualitative differences in the absorption spectra are associated not with the palladium precursors used but with the preparation methods. The spectra of the IWI-prepared samples 3A and 3B (Fig. 3) exhibit the features characteristic of Pd/Al2O3 as well as unique ones. Along with the charge transfer band at 200 nm, which is partially overlapped by the fundamental absorption boundary of MgO and can only be described qualitatively, the main charge transfer band is located at 248 nm (3B) and 254 nm (3A). For samples 1A, 1B, and 2B, the maximum of the charge transfer band is located at 280 nm. In the case of sample 2A, a mixed state was apparently observed, when both the bands at 250 and 280 nm are present in the absorption spectrum. Fig. S2 (Supplementary Information) shows the diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra of samples 1B, 2B, and 3B with a curve fitting by a Gaussian function and a Tauc plot characterizing the band-gap (Eg) values of the PdO species. Additional experiments for the samples calcined at 800 °C (Fig. S3, Supplementary Information) showed a decrease in the differences in the Pd2+ coordination environment due to the metal-support interactions associated with the differences in the preparation methods. All the samples demonstrate a d-d transition band at ∼450 nm and a metal-ligand charge transfer band at 240 nm. At the same time, only for sample 3B, there is a noticeable decrease in the Eg value (2.06 eV), which indicates the beginning of the PdO sintering. Samples 1A and 1B show the lowest intensity of the absorption bands (Fig. 3a and b, spectrum 2). In this case, the decoration of the PdO particles by the MgO support can be supposed. Contrarily, for samples 3A and 3B, the PdO particles are obviously located on the surface of the support. The variations in the shape of the charge transition bands can be explained by the presence of the distinctions in the coordination environment of Pd2+ caused by the differences in the preparation method used and metal-support interactions between PdO and MgO. The band gap width (Eg) values of PdO species determined from the UV–vis spectra are presented in Table 1. As seen, these values range from 2.0 to 2.31 eV. The band gap value is known to be affected by the particle size [47]. However, in this case, a large contribution is made by the rearrangement of the coordination environment of Pd2+, which characterizes different metal-support interaction strengths for the samples synthesized by different methods. Similar effects have been already reported in the literature. For instance, Peng et al. [28] have studied a series of Pd/MgO catalysts with the PdO concentrations varied in a range of 0.1–2 wt% and observed an increase in the Eg values (1.93–2.09 eV) with the rise in the Pd content. At the same time, the particle size was almost the same (4.1–4.5 nm), and the observed effect was explained by the PdO-MgO interactions. The H2-TPR data for a series of the Pd/MgO catalysts are presented in Fig. 4 a. Since all the samples were calcined at 500 °C in air, all palladium in the samples is expected to be in the form of Pd2+ species. It is well known that some species of palladium oxide PdO can be reduced at room temperature. The resulting Pd particles are capable of forming palladium β-hydride, which decomposes at temperatures of 60–90 °C [56,57]. Such an effect was not found in the samples under study, thus indicating that most of the palladium oxide requires higher temperatures to be reduced. For samples 1A, 1B, and 2B, pronounced peaks in the temperature range of 70–75 °C associated with the reduction of PdO are observed [28,58]. The hydrogen uptake caused by the reduction of more dispersed palladium species strongly interacting with magnesium oxide is expected at higher temperatures [58]. Al-Doghachi et al. [59] and Aytam et al. [60] attributed the hydrogen uptake in the temperature range of 150–300 °C to the reduction of PdO. The most intense peaks in this temperature range are observed for samples 2A and 3A prepared using the precursor [Pd(NH3)4](NO3)2. The remaining samples also show the hydrogen uptake in this region, but the peaks are less intense and shifted towards high temperatures. It is worth noting that the uptake can also be associated with a hydrogen spillover from palladium to magnesium oxide [58]. According to the literature [60,61], the uptake in the temperature range of 400–500 °C observed for all the Pd/MgO samples can be assigned to this process. Fig. 4b demonstrates the TPHD profiles for the Pd/MgO samples. The negative peak at 85 °C seems to be due to the release of hydrogen from the decomposition of palladium hydride of non-stoichiometric composition (PdHx). The value of x for bulk hydride is about 0.6–0.7 and decreases with increasing metal dispersion [62,63]. The highest hydrogen release ratio (N(H)/N(Pd)) was observed for the sample 1A (0.21). For samples 1B and 2B, this ratio was 0.09 and 0.08, respectively. No hydrogen release was registered for the remaining samples. Thus, it can be assumed that the palladium particle size increases in a row: 3A ≈ 3B ≈ 2A < 1B ≈ 2B < 1A. It is worth noting that there is a clear correlation between the results of the TPR and UV–vis methods. Thus, samples 1A, 1B, and 2B are characterized by the presence of well-reduced palladium species. For these samples only, the release of hydrogen during the TPHD experiments was observed. Finally, the UV–vis spectra for all these three samples are quite similar and characterized by a relatively low intensity of charge transfer bands and inhomogeneously broadened d-d transitions band of Pd2+. Samples 2A and 3A showed the largest number of strongly bound palladium species, and at the same time, intensive charge transfer and d-d transition bands were observed in their UV–vis spectra. Additionally, these samples are characterized by low Eg values (1.98–2.05 eV). TEM images of the aerogel-prepared samples 1A and 1B in the reduced state are shown in Fig. 5 . The structure of the samples is formed by prolonged needle-shaped and rounded MgO crystallites (Fig. 5a and d). On the surface of these crystallites, a large number of step-site defects can be seen (Fig. 5e). Palladium formed metallic particles with an average diameter of 4.3 and 8.4 nm in the case of samples 1B and 1A, respectively. In certain cases, the surface of Pd particles was found to be oxidized, which probably occurred after the samples were exposed to air after reduction (Fig. 5b). The metal particles are located mostly at the outer surface of the MgO agglomerates. TEM images of the samples 2A and 3A are presented in Fig. 6 . In the case of xerogel and IWI-prepared catalysts, no needle-shaped MgO crystallites are observed (Fig. 6a and d). The disappearance of these crystallites is obviously caused by drying under the ambient conditions in the case of the sample 2B and exposure to water during the impregnation stage followed by drying in the case of the sample 3A. The MgO crystallites, however, did not lose their highly defect surface structure (Fig. 6b and e). In both cases, very fine Pd metallic particles are formed: an average particle size is estimated to be 2.0 nm and 2.2 nm for samples 2A and 3A, respectively. Both samples are characterized by a very narrow particle size distribution (Fig. 6c and f). As mentioned previously, the average pore size in these samples is 7.8 nm and 10.1 nm, respectively. Therefore, the smaller Pd particles can be located inside the porous network of MgO. Also, it is important to note that the TEM data correlate well with the TPR and TPHD data. In the XPS spectra of all samples, the lines attributed to Pd, Mg, O, and C are present. Magnesium in the samples is in only one state (Fig. S4, Supplementary Information), with the BE value of the Mg 2p line of about 50.5 eV, which is characteristic of Mg2+ in the MgO oxide [48,49]. The O 1s line at 530.8 eV can be assigned to the oxygen in MgO (Fig. S5, Supplementary Information). The BE value of 533.2 eV corresponds to the hydroxyl groups or adsorbed oxygen on the surface [48,49]. In addition, the atomic ratio O/Mg is close to 1 for all samples (Table 2 ), thus corresponding to the stoichiometry of MgO. From the analysis of the shape and half-width of the Pd 3d spectra (Fig. 7 ), it can be concluded that in all samples under study, palladium is characterized with the BE value of the Pd 3d5/2 line of about 335.5 eV, which is typical for Pd nanoparticles in the metal state [64]. At the same time, a slight increase in the BE can be seen in row 1A < 2A << 3A. This corresponds to a sequential decrease in electron density on the Pd particles, probably due to their interaction with the support. The BE values, however, remain substantially less than that for PdO. In the same series, the surface concentration of palladium increases. This result correlates well with the previously presented data. In the case of sample 1A, the lower Pd/Mg ratio is due to the large size of palladium particles. For sample 2A, the Pd particles are localized inside the porous structure of magnesium oxide. Moreover, they can strongly interact with the support, and this interaction can be expressed, for example, by the formation of PdO-MgO solid solutions, which cannot be reduced under these conditions [65]. In the IWI-prepared sample 3A, the palladium particles are obviously located on the surface, which results in the highest Pd/Mg ratio. The obtained results can be summarized as follows. The aerogel-prepared samples demonstrate large Pd particles located on the outer surface of the MgO matrix. In contrast, xerogel and IWI methods allowed for preparing small Pd particles. These particles interact strongly with the MgO support, which results in the decrease of electron density on these particles, as confirmed by XPS. In the case of the aerogel-prepared samples 1A and 1B, the enlargement of Pd particles takes place during the supercritical drying stage. For these samples, during the drying under supercritical conditions, the active component adsorbs on the support surface in competition with the supercritical solvent, which leads to the fact that palladium is located mainly on the outer surface and, consequently, to the formation of larger particles. In addition, it can be supposed that the decomposition of the precursor, Pd(NO3)2 or [Pd(NH3)4](NO3)2, also occurs during the supercritical drying and the subsequent calcination with the formation of PdO. Note that the decomposition temperatures of Pd(NO3)2 and [Pd(NH3)4](NO3)2 are 165–275 °C [66] and 220–260 °C [67], correspondingly. The reduction of PdO with CH3OH resulted in the formation of enlarged Pd particles. For sample 2A prepared by the xerogel method, the processes of the formation of the porous structure of the support and the adsorption of the precursor at the active sites being formed were resolved in time. Therefore, the competitive adsorption mode was not realized, which made it possible, as in the case of the synthesis of sample 3A, to obtain a more uniform distribution of the active component over the surface of the support. The different particle sizes of palladium species in the samples of series A and B are due to the differences in the ligand composition of the palladium flat-square complexes and, as a consequence, the different nature of the interaction with the surface, as well as possibly the thermal effects at the calcination stage, affecting, as mentioned earlier, the formation of the texture. While in the case of sample 1A, palladium was mainly in the [Pd(NH3)4]2+ state, in the case of sample 1B, an ion nitrate can be expected to enter the coordination sphere to form such species as [Pd(H2O)2(NO3)2], [Pd(H2O)3NO3]+, and [Pd(H2O)2(OH)NO3] as well as palladium aqua complexes [68]. In the presence of MgO, however, it is possible to neutralize the excess amount of HNO3 present in the acidic commercial solution of palladium nitrate, which leads to an increase in pH and precipitation of palladium hydroxide. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the Pd/MgO catalysts in the acetylene hydrogenation The results of catalytic tests of the Pd/MgO samples in the acetylene hydrogenation reaction are shown in Fig. 8 . It should be noted that each sample was tested at least three times. The reproducibility of the catalytic performance is illustrated by the error bars. The comparison of the catalytic data shows that the aerogel-prepared samples exhibit the greatest activity along with the best reproducibility. As can be seen from Fig. 8a, the acetylene conversion curves for these catalysts (samples 1A and 1B) are located in the region of lower temperatures: the temperature of reaching 50 % conversion of acetylene (T50) is 35–37 °C. The samples synthesized by two other methods are characterized by less activity. For xerogels (samples 2A and 2B), the T50 value is found to be 49 °C, while for the catalysts 3A and 3B obtained by IWI of aerogel-prepared MgO with palladium precursor solutions, the T50 value is ∼ 65 °C regardless of the palladium precursor. Additionally, to compare the samples, the turnover frequency (TOF) values at 40 °C were calculated from the average particle size according to HR TEM. For the most active sample 1A, which was synthesized by aerogel method using ammonium palladium nitrate complex, the TOF value of 34.7 c−1 exceeds that for the IWI-prepared sample 3A (2.5 c−1), and the xerogel-prepared sample 2A (3.2 c−1) by 13.8 and 10.8 times, respectively. These three catalysts were prepared using the same palladium precursor. Moreover, sample 1A is in 2.3 times more active than the aerogel catalyst 1B obtained using palladium nitrate (14.8 c−1). According to the HR TEM data, the most active catalyst 1A contains sufficiently large palladium particles with an average diameter of 8.4 nm, while the less active samples obtained by xerogel (2A) and IWI (3A), on the contrary, include more dispersed palladium particles with an average diameter of ∼ 2 nm. It is worth noting that the acetylene hydrogenation reaction is structurally sensitive in the region of small particle sizes [69–71]. Therefore, the effect of palladium particle size on catalytic activity is quite natural. Thus, the results obtained in this work are well consistent with the data of other researchers [70,71]. For example, as reported by Ryndin et al. [70] for Pd/C catalysts, an increase in the particle size of Pd from ∼ 2 to 3.5 nm leads to an increase in TOF by 3–4 times. The further enlargement of particles does not affect the TOF values remarkably. It seems that the higher activity of less dispersed palladium particles in the aerogel-prepared samples 1A and 1B can be explained by the higher availability of the active sites due to their localization on the outer surface of MgO. The lower activity of the more dispersed particles in samples 2A and 3A may have several explanations. First, according to H2-TPR data, dispersed palladium particles in these catalysts interact more strongly with the support, which explains their electron deficiency according to the XPS data. Adsorption of unsaturated hydrocarbons on low-ordinated palladium atoms is characterized by an increased strength, which results in reversible poisoning of the catalyst surface and, most likely, causes a decrease in activity [72]. Second, the part of the active component localized in the narrow pores of the support may remain inaccessible to the reactant. For the xerogel samples, blocking of palladium nanoparticles by the support could not also be excluded, since the processes of the support formation and the adsorption of the palladium precursor in this case took place simultaneously. As known, the texture characteristics of the catalyst have an important influence on its properties [73]. Thus, the differences in the properties of the samples under study can also be due to the peculiarities of their porous structure and the associated diffusion restrictions. Fig. 9 shows the linear dependence of the activity of the catalysts 1A, 1B, 2A, and 3A on the reaction temperature in the Arrhenius coordinates for the temperature intervals corresponding to low acetylene conversion values. The aerogel sample 1A is characterized by the highest value of the apparent activation energy (74.9 kJ/mol), which indicates that the kinetic mode of the catalytic reaction is realized due to the availability of the active sites. The smallest apparent activation energy of 33.2 kJ/mol is inherent for the IWI-prepared catalyst 3A. The acetylene hydrogenation process occurs over this sample in the transition region due to diffusion constraints. The values of the apparent activation energy for samples 1B and 2A are close, which allows us to talk about the close nature of the active sites in these catalysts. The smaller number of available active sites in the xerogel-prepared catalyst 2A does not appear to be caused by diffusion restrictions, as in the case of sample 3A. This is most likely due to the blockage of a part of the active component by the support during the synthesis. Despite the similar pore radii in the catalysts 2A and 3A, the sample 2A is characterized by a large mesopore content (> 20 nm), which seems to result in more efficient transport of alkyne molecules to the palladium particles. The method for preparing the Pd/MgO catalyst also has a significant influence on the selectivity in the hydrogenation reaction. As can be seen from the temperature dependencies of ethylene selectivity (Fig. 8b), the aerogel-supported samples are the most selective in the low-temperature region. However, the selectivity decreases rapidly with the temperature increase, primarily by increasing the contribution of the process of complete acetylene hydrogenation to ethane (Fig. 8c). A similar relationship is also characteristic of the sample 2B. The cause of the observed phenomena may be a larger palladium particle size (dav = 4–8 nm) in these systems. For the sample 2B, this is indirectly confirmed by the results of UV–vis, TPR, and TPHD. As is known [71,74,75], palladium is capable of volumetric absorption of hydrogen to form a phase of palladium β-hydride. Moreover, the tendency of palladium to dissolve hydrogen increases with increasing particle size [14]. At the same time, the presence of β-PdH is undesirable for the hydrogenation process, since it reduces its selectivity due to the participation of "hydride" hydrogen in the reaction of acetylene conversion to ethane [14]. As found by the TPHD method (Fig. 4b), palladium in the composition of samples 1A, 1B, and 2B is capable of dissolving hydrogen to form β-PdH, which inevitably worsens their selectivity. The catalysts 2A, 3A, and 3B are less selective to ethylene than the aerogel samples in the reaction temperature range of 20–50 °C. Along with this, there is no sharp decrease in selectivity with increasing the reaction temperature. Some decrease in the ethylene selectivity is observed at temperatures above 60 °C, which seems to be due to diffusion limitations caused by the features of the porous structure of these samples. Under such conditions, the probability of the ethylene readsorption during its movement through the pore system to the surface of the catalyst grain increases. This facilitates its complete hydrogenation to ethane, as evidenced by a synchronous increase in the proportion of ethane among the reaction products at temperatures above 60 °C. Thus, the aerogel-prepared Pd/MgO catalysts have good activity in the hydrogenation of acetylene. There is a challenge to achieve high selectivity toward ethylene for high acetylene conversions. But, the good perspectives also have MgO-supported catalysts with ultra-low palladium content [37]. In addition, it should be noted that in practice, palladium catalysts modified with silver, zinc, copper, and other transition metals are used. According to our expectations, modification of the aerogel-supported palladium with a second metal should give the possibility to achieve both high activity due to the absence of diffusion restrictions and high selectivity and stability, which will be ensured by the presence of a bimetallic phase. These two approaches are the basis for future research aimed at improving aerogel-prepared Pd/MgO catalysts. 4 Conclusions In the present research, a series of Pd/MgO catalysts were prepared via the sol-gel procedure with the addition of palladium precursors to a freshly obtained magnesium hydroxide gel. The drying procedure was performed using two different approaches: drying under supercritical conditions, and thermal drying at atmospheric pressure. The catalysts prepared by a conventional incipient wetness impregnation method were used as reference samples. It has been found that the preparation method, as well as the type of palladium precursor, has a significant effect on the porous structure of the support, the dispersion of the active metal (Pd), and its localization. All these factors influence the catalytic performance of the samples. Thus, the aerogel-prepared catalysts demonstrated the greatest activity in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene into ethylene. Thus, the 50 % acetylene conversion with selectivity toward ethylene of ∼60 % was achieved at 37 °C over the Pd/MgO catalyst prepared via the aerogel route using [Pd(NH3)4](NO3)2. The key factors here were the optimal size of the metal particles (4–8 nm) and the high textural characteristics of the support. In the case of other preparation methods, the smaller size of the palladium particles helps to enhance the metal-support interaction. A sequential decrease in the electron density on the Pd particles due to their interaction with the support can be seen in a row: aerogel samples < xerogel samples << IWI samples. For the samples prepared by the xerogel technique, palladium is evenly distributed throughout the catalyst's granule. In the case of the IWI-prepared samples, palladium is located mostly on the surface. These two factors stipulate lower catalytic activity of the samples obtained using the xerogel approach (T50 of ∼49 °C with selectivity less than 44 %), which still turns out to be more effective than the IWI-prepared catalysts (T50 of ∼64 °C with selectivity not exceeding 50 %) due to more developed textural characteristics. It should be expected that the "xerogel" samples are able to exhibit a high efficiency in processes, in which the role of diffusion is less significant. Thus, the promise of the sol-gel method for the preparation of the Pd/MgO catalysts is demonstrated. The variation of the preparation method allows the characteristics of the catalysts to be changed in a controlled manner to achieve maximum efficiency in the desired process. coredata.dc:description: In the present work, an alkoxide sol-gel method was applied to prepare Pd/MgO catalysts. The sol-gel procedure was followed by supercritical drying (aerogels) or conventional drying (xerogels) in a furnace. These materials were compared with the impregnated samples. The Pd loading was 1 wt% in all the cases. The as-prepared catalysts were characterized by a set of physicochemical methods. Both the type of the Pd precursor and the preparation route were found to affect the porous structure of the materials as well as the dispersion of the palladium particles and their localization over the MgO support. Both the xerogel and incipient wetness impregnation methods lead to a narrower pore size distribution in comparison to the aerogel technique. The most dispersed particles with an average size of ∼ 2.0–2.2 nm were observed for the samples prepared by xerogel and impregnation methods. In the case of aerogel-prepared samples, metallic palladium particles possess bimodal distribution with average diameters of 4.3 and 8.4 nm. The best catalytic performance in acetylene hydrogenation to ethylene (50 % acetylene conversion at 37 °C with selectivity ∼60 %) was observed for the Pd/MgO catalyst prepared via the aerogel route using [Pd(NH3)4](NO3)2. Compared to other samples, this material is characterized by relatively weak metal-support interactions and the availability of active sites for reactants, which ensures the kinetic mode of the hydrogenation reaction (Ea = 74.9 kJ/mol).
coredata.dc:title: Effect of preparation conditions of nanocrystalline Pd/MgO catalysts on their performance in selective hydrogenation of acetylene
